posts.name: ahartnet
posts.cooked:
Got around to screwing with the robot arm kit on the Romi. Pretty fun! The code I have can be found here (largely based on ZQ and R^2): GitHub - Pearadox/Romi

One of the things I’m struggling with though is the servos are very twitchy. I started down a path of trying to look at some wpilib documentation for servo deadbands (the setbounds function) or something else, but no luck. It’d also be great if I could figure out how to print out the pulse width it’s currently at so I can try to set it up to match the Romi documentation. Anyone have suggestions for making the servos less twitchy? I suspect it’s just from trying to maintain a setpoint from the weight of the arm pulling it down and overcorrecting, but it seems like there should be a decent way of managing that? I’ve also tried disconnecting the gripper and wrist servos to see if it was just noise, and had the arm in the full down position so that it didn’t have extraneous force on it (the servo horn was facing straight up) and it still is twitchy.

It also seems that there’s not a good way to set what the default servo set point is when the robot is disabled, or at least from my reading of the documentation. That’s definitely workable, so not a huge deal - but want to make sure I’m not missing anything there either.

Here’s a video showing the twitchiness. I’ve got a 5V, 3.2A step down voltage regulator , getting Vin from VSW: https://photos.app.goo.gl/aEtb5SBQTXjaohaQ8

Some pictures of the set up just cause: image 1772×1329 599 KB

posts.name: zeequeue
posts.cooked:
The Romi takes in angle values (via servo.setAngle() ) and maps it from [0,180] degrees to [544,2400] microseconds.

Re: twitching, one thing to try is to try to actuate the servos without them being connected to the arm (just to make sure it’s not something going on with the firmware/servos themselves). On my romi with the arm, i did see a little bit of buzzing while lowering the arm.

Yeah the default setpoint is a little… weird. We wanted to make sure that if you connected a PWM motor controller or continuous rotation servo, that they would stop upon reset/disable (since we don’t have a good way of cutting bus power).

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked:
The way I dealt with these two issues is the same way I did it for the gripper.

Default position. Detach the servo horns and power the robot (running the code). Change the angle of the horn  so it positions the arm where I want it to be in neutral and reattach (I may have done this powered off without disconnecting the servo).

Remap the joystick so that the joystick outputs 0-1 rather than -1 -+1.

I do hear the servos in disabled mode. I guess you could account for that in software by setting them to a more stable value in disabledInit().

posts.name: ahartnet
posts.cooked:
Is your Romi arm twitchy while in teleoperated too?

I’ll disassemble the arm/wrist from the servos tomorrow to see if their twitchy without the weight of the arm.

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked:
I have not been using the arm lately so do not remember how bad it was, but I definitely think it was twitchy when I first got everything running. I do remember that when both the gripper angle and the lift servo were working against each other, it was twitchy. I will look into it when I get a chance.

You may be able to play with the scale more to smooth it like you would a motor, but it may not work the same since we are setting angles not velocity.

It is interesting. The Vex kits use regular motors for the gripper arm. I feel the servos are better suited to the task.

posts.name: ahartnet
posts.cooked:
zeequeue:

The Romi takes in angle values (via servo.setAngle() ) and maps it from [0,180] degrees to [544,2400] microseconds.

This is very helpful, thanks! Is this in the wpilib documentation for servos somewhere that I missed? Or is it specific to the Romi in some way?

posts.name: zeequeue
posts.cooked: It’s Romi-specific…ish. The firmware uses the arduino servo library, and specifically the writeAngle call, which does the mapping I mentioned above

In my experience, servo twitchiness is kind of par for the course. It usually seems to happen when the analog PWM waveform is near the transition between two discrete setpoints, as interpreted by the servo’s internal controller. Sometimes a slight nudge to the requested angle can stabilize the situation and stop the twitch/buzz. It is definitely related to resonance in the physical system being controlled.

I think the problem is compounded in the Arduino firmware, where the standard servo libraries take an integer angle, meaning that there are a limited number of command-able setpoints between 0 and 180 degrees. The underlying resolution of the PWM hardware is typically much more capable.

It might help to tighten all the bolts and add a few drops of Locktite. My Romi arm dismantles itself regularly.

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked: I got ours working relatively smoothly.  There are some times when the arm and the wrist servos fight one another, but it is smooth for the most part. I put the arm on the Yaxis and the wrist on the Xaxis of a game controller (but also put low and high on buttons. You all probably know the map formula, but here is what we use for conversion just in case it could help anyone. output = (((input-inputLowerLimit)/inputRange)*outputRange)+outputLowerLimit;

posts.name: Jason Rubenstein
posts.cooked:
I think there’s too much current draw to run all three servos through the on-board 5V voltage regulator.  Each servo needs up to 1.9A, and the voltage regulator is 2A max.

Mine was very twitchy too, but then if I run a single servo only it’s fine.

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked:
Yes, and, the gripper servo is much smaller, so if you choose only one, that is the one I would run off the onboard regulator.

As a side note, we have a bunch of old Vex EDR stock that was donated to us, and the motor controller 29s work well as motor controllers that do not need any soldering. We plug a voltage regulator into VSwitched, then run from that into the V+ rail, and the motor controllers are practically plug-and-play.

We have a few of the 3-wire vex motors with built-in controllers that work too (To be honest, I am not sure how they differ from continuous servos).

Another note. We actually burned out one of the arms servos (they do not like being moved with no power). The brackets fit most standard servos, and the pinon is significantly more standard than I thought it would be. So, if this happens to you, they are replaceable without necessitating an entirely new arm purchase.

Also, Pololu does sell the gripper and the servo mounts separately (They include .step files for the mounts as well).

link_counts.title: Pololu - Micro Gripper Kit with Position Feedback Servo
Pololu - Mounting Bracket for Standard-Size Servos

posts.cooked:
We recently received a donation of a bunch of Vex stuff that I’ve been looking at using with the Romi. The 3-wire “motors” do appear to be continuous servos.

Until now we’ve used LEGO and 3D printing for our Romi mechanisms, but the Vex stuff might be more appealing to some of the students who still think the Romi is just a toy.

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked:
That is excellent. We got many of the Vex pieces working with the Romi. The ultrasonic sensor is a no-go though (It would probably work, but would require a lower-level class that accesses the Romi hardware directly). I do not think the timing is accurate enough.  For us, using the Romi as the brain of a vex-based bot is actually much easier than using the old Vex Cortex software. The programming is just different enough that it was confusing for some of our members.

The other thing we are working on is using the Vex hardware with a RIO, and making a mini FRC bot like the Rev one we see popping up in some of the tutorials from time to time.

While we do not have the full bot together yet, the benchtop test is working pretty well actually. We are using a 12-volt battery from Studica to power it, but have tried a vex battery which works as well (we got a bit more brazen with our oldest Rio now that we are one of the lucky teams to have ordered a RIO 2.0 while it was in stock).

If memory serves, the PWM mapping between the motor control 29 and the WPILib Motor PWM motor classes is not perfect, but there are some that are close (I think we tend to use Sparks). This distinction may make you think at first that the motor controller will not work, but it is not all that different than the Servo issues.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
Can you clarify what piece of information was necessary? There’s a few things I can think of, but most seem to be in the docs.

That the servo class is what is used. Romi Hardware Support — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation That the servo setAngle is from 0-180. Repeatable Low Power Movement - Controlling Servos with WPILib — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation That the servo PWM pulse range for the Romi is [544,2400] microseconds. I don’t see this documented, but it doesn’t seem very important.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Thanks for the links. Specifically there is nothing saying Romi’s arm servos only function properly with the setAngle() method. By chance, we tried set() , setPosition() , and even setVelocity() before finding this CD post. Although the documentation says set() scales the PWM value to move the servo to the extremes, we could not get this to work. The setBounds() method appeared to have no effect and set() did not move the servo to each extreme.

In the Romi documentation we found PWM ranges, but no indication if they are compatible with HS-322HD servos. We started with the claw and found documentation that says it has a range of 500 µs (fully open) to 2400 µs (fully closed) and that this is a larger range than a typical RC servo. You say the ranges don’t seem very important, but they indicate the range of motion when the arm is properly assembled. The range is needed to write code to fully close and open the claw.

When we found this CD post pointing us to setAngle() we had no way to map the PWM ranges to angles, so we had to discover each servos range of motion in degrees ourselves. Given what I know now, that is the direction I will give kids - add getAngle() to the smartdashboard and manually move the servos to the extremes to discover the ranges.

To summarize, how would we know that the set() , setPosition() , and setVelocity() methods will not allow for full range of motion, and that the setBounds() method does not do anything so the PWM ranges are irrelevant?

link_counts.title: Pololu - 4. Using the Robot Arm for Romi

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
gdefender:

Thanks for the links. Specifically there is nothing saying Romi’s arm servos only function properly with the setAngle() method. By chance, we tried set() , setPosition() , and even setVelocity() before finding this CD post. Although the documentation says set() scales the PWM value to move the servo to the extremes, we could not get this to work. The setBounds() method appeared to have no effect and set() did not move the servo to each extreme.

Just to clarify, did you see different behavior between set and setAngle? They both should have the exact same effect (ie set of 0 and setAngle of 0 do the same thing and set of 1 and setAngle of 180 do the same thing).

gdefender:

Given what I know now, that is the direction I will give kids - add getAngle() to the smartdashboard and manually move the servos to the extremes to discover the ranges.

Unfortunately, getAngle won’t do what you want. It returns the position that the servo was commanded. In a normal servo, the feedback potentiometer has no external connection. Since the Romi Arm servos do have an extra pin for the potentiometer, you could use an analog input to read them.
